titleStmt.title: Pabilsa&g;'s journey to Nibru -- an English prose translation

publicationStmt.distributor: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature

address.addrLine: The Oriental Institute, University of Oxford, Pusey Lane, Oxford OX1 2LE, UK, email etcsl@orinst.ox.ac.uk, http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk

seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

sourceDesc.p: Sources are listed in the header of the composite text

div1.p: The wild bull with brindled thighs, whose house is noble! My king, the wild bull with brindled thighs, whose house is noble! Pabilsa&g;, the wild bull with brindled thighs, whose house is noble! His house, the house of Larag, is noble, his house is noble! His city, a mighty city, is abundant, and his house is noble! The warrior's house is the house of Larag; Lord Pabilsa&g;'s city is a mighty city &X;&X;. His birthplace was the shrine Nibru &X;&X;. The place where he drank good milk was the house &X;&X;. From the place, the pure place, &X;&X;. Isin, the unique house &X;&X;. The place which the bull embraces &X;&X;. Like a scorpion rising up from among the thorns, he is a fearsome scorpion; like a wolf rising up from his lair, he is likely to growl; like a lion rising up in the pathway, he is likely to beat &X;&X;.

At that time, he wished to dig (?) in the meadows; the lord wished to dig (?) in the meadows. Lord Pabilsa&g; wished to dig (?) in the meadows; in all the meadows of Isin, my king wished to dig (?). So then my king set off for Nibru.

And as the warrior Pabilsa&g; set off in Enlil's direction, as he he set off, now he turned (?) in front of that house in Isin. And then my lady in Isin came out &X;&X;. At the spacious house, the house of Isin, she &X;&X; her hair, then she &X;&X; the hair in curls (?) &X;&X;. Her headdress was loosened. She addressed Pabilsa&g; joyfully: Good-looking &X;&X; the house of Isin! Warrior Pabilsa&g; &X;&X; borne to Nintur! You who are travelling from (?) Larag to &X;&X; that house in Isin, say to your father, May she be my spouse! Say further to Enlil, &X;&X; with me! Fix your sights on it, fix your sights on it, and may you be its lord! The house of Isin &X;&X;. May you, Pabilsa&g;, be its lord, and may I be its lady!

div1.note: It is possible, but less likely, that Segment B belongs after Segment D
div1.p: (Enlil speaks:) &X;&X; and may its flax be flax! &X;&X; and may its grain be grain! &X;&X; may its &X;&X; be good for eating.

And now, under that very sun and on that day, so it really happened. &X;&X; waved their tails in the Kir-sig watercourse, waved &X;&X;. &X;&X; established the house &X;&X;. &X;&X; the most righteous &X;&X;. &X;&X; the good bull-calf, the ruler &X;&X;. &X;&X; established the house &X;&X;. &X;&X; its flax was flax. &X;&X; its grain was grain. &X;&X; its &X;&X; was good for eating.

Ninisina &X;&X;. In the Kir-sig watercourse &X;&X; their tails &X;&X; Isin &X;&X;. Joyfully his son married a wife &X;&X;; joyfully Lord Pabilsa&g; married Ninisina &X;&X;. She &X;&X; him the digging implement for the Kir-sig watercourse. &X;&X; their tails &X;&X; Isin &X;&X; for him.

Enlil stood beside the river and spoke to it. He stood beside the Kir-sig watercourse and &X;&X;: River, may &X;&X; your outlet be &X;&X; for him. May you establish &X;&X; the house here. &X;&X; the most righteous &X;&X;, &X;&X; great wild bull &X;&X;.

But Pabilsa&g; would not eat (?) the bull in his mouth; nor would &X;&X; Pabilsa&g; eat (?) the sheep in his mouth. He did not rub the &X;&X; pot &X;&X;. Don't go &X;&X; to &X;&X;. They raised the &X;&X; lament, and put &X;&X;. They raised Lord Pabilsa&g;, and put &X;&X;. They set him down (?) in the city of his sister. His sister came out to him from the house.
But Pabilsa&g; would not eat (?) the bull in his mouth; nor would &X;&X; Pabilsa&g; eat (?) the sheep in his mouth. He did not rub the &X;&X; pot &X;&X;. Don't go &X;&X;!
